ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Lots of Spanish grammar and speaking skills as well as developing comfort.
Knowledge of many verb tenses and lots of vocabulary.

You'll learn around 5 new tenses and hundreds of new vocabulary words. Class meets daily except Wednesday, and is wholly conducted in Spanish --- the product of that daily practice and immersion should be an improvement in your Spanish, but you have to be engaged with the course.

I learned 
-the different uses of por vs para
-the importance of accents for different intepretations and tenses
-Nature vocabulary
-Car vocabulary
-Career vocabulary
-City/Living vocabulary
-House vocabulary
-Imperfect past test
-perfect future tense
-Preterit past tense
-How to use sources that are in Spanish to conduct research
-SLight differences in vocabulary in different spanish-speaking counties

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think more forced in person small group talking not through the slideshow where after we have to share what we talked about or found
Not enough spoken Spanish. Too many people spoke English in class which made it difficult

I think it's great that it's every day because it creates a steady workflow. I think the structure of the lessons needs to be changed, though. It feels way too much like grinding through a bunch of tasks each day, whereas opportunities for informal conversation might be much more valuable. For instance, extended discussions in small groups (maybe for the entire class) would help us practice what we are learning in a conversational setting.

Strengths: Sra. Alexandrov is an accessible, caring instructor, who will do her best to make the class enjoyable and worth your while. I wholeheartedly recommend her as an instructor. The course is difficult, but you will end up improving your Spanish.

Weaknesses: Just about everything else. The way Spanish is structured at Yale, the Professor doesn't teach any content (grammar, vocabulary, anything) in class -- students are responsible for learning everything on their own through the online textbook. The Professor is just there to chaperone daily practice with the students -- which can be fun, but is more often tedious and frustrating. There's daily homework as well -- it's also graded through the online textbook. 

One might think that given the amount of work the Spanish program expects students to put into the course, grading would be somewhat sympathetic. Think again. Grading is remarkably harsh; you'll lose full points on tests and homework for missing accents and misplaced pronouns, even if you get the verb and the form right. There's absolutely no curve -- despite the fact that students have to spend at least half an hour a day on homework, half an hour on lessons, and additional time on practice, you'll need a 94 for an A.

I believe this course needs to force students to use their Spanish a bit more. I would suggest more speaking in class and potentially trips to different places locally to enable this use in real practice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, it was a very solid Spanish level two class

Yes. It gives you a ton of Spanish learning in a short amount of time. Stay on top of things and find ways to enjoy learning Spanish and it will be a bright spot in your day. There is daily homework but it is definitely manageable.

If you have the time and the discipline to commit an hour and a half each day to Spanish homework and practice --- or, if you're ok not getting an A --- then yes, go for it. The pace is fast, the grading is harsh, and no matter how understanding your professor is, they'll stick to the syllabus. You will improve your Spanish if you put in the work --- but you might work really hard and still not get an A. 

The real reason to take the class is the fact that Spanish is one of the most useful and enjoyable languages to know. It's an ok reason to give up a lot of time and a bit of your gpa. 

I certainly recommend taking Sra. Alexandrov's section if it is available.
I would recommend this course for establishing some Spanish basics and to improve vocabulary.
